author: @falahsheikh4535

comment:
"Out with the old....

....in with the cat girls eyyyyyyyyy am i rite tho???"

And yeah, it seems like a decision engine.

Who actually made it?  And I don't mean OpenAI, I mean who, because Sam doesn't strike me as someone who designed the core of the engine, no real offense either, it could be a function of being a CEO, but unfortunately putting on a public mask (the figurative one lol) on your ability to communicate design and function is also a mask that follows you in private and will always affect you in some way.  That will affect your design (as well influence on the design AND designers) before, during and after.

Now if it is Sam and there is no mask, then they really don't know how it works lol (yikes).  And the reason I ask, is because the designer(s),especially the core foundation, are who should be the face of something like this, human needs/systems aside (the corporate bullshit).  And then, that face should maybe be a bit more concerned about function and less "in awe".  [Never mind lol, I found one of the main guys, you can tell within the first few sentences of them talking about the subject even before their work hahahah, ah, I love it.  It really is just that easy sometimes.  LMAO : within 3 minutes of talking Ilya says it all, oh man, please CEO's : listen to AND LEARN FROM your scientists and engineers ]

"...aligned..."  ;  "aligned" ; "more aligned"  ...ALIGNED TO WHAT LOL!?  My dude, I'm not even convinced by the more apocalyptic thinkers, but I can see exactly why they are concerned if this is how you refer to this system.  It's probably your evals, but the thing is...that just doesn't mean anything if you can't explain it in 1 or 2 sentences that summarize what that alignment really means.  This is my (and potentially many other people's) concern with these companies, they are just to afraid to clearly state what they do not know and you end up with this facade where they aren't allowed to say it, but everything they say just doesn't really answer anything.

Sam is saying the right "thing", align before advancement so to speak, but do you even really understand that?  You can't really advance an appreciable and noticible distance before you realize you aren't aligned anymore.  This is a control problem.  I don't even think it is really solvable, but understanding core function can help with mitigation in the event of problems that lead to accountability, assuming such a thing is a factor ..lol.

Here's a neat tid bit from Lex's commentary : the people who call people like Jordan Peterson a fascist, learn more about those people.  The 2 I know are almost certainly sociopaths of some sort, as in rather than understanding the nature of reality they instead insert their agendas into situations in manipulative ways to try to get a desired outcome.  That's just 2 I personally know, but I've seen the rampant behavior before, it became especially more prominent as the internet nerd paradise slowly died and gave way to what we have now, that's when that mentality among others showed up and everything just got worse.  This is a very interesting aside actually, these types of people will have a tendency to "hallucinate" details in order to fit their own idea of a reward, that is to attribute to their current model of reality as oppose to accepting the failure and entering a retrial stage.  I would not be surprised if ChatGPT models are more "aligned" than you think they are....they just happen to be aligned to horseshit. 

That's also how you know someone isn't capable of good science, at least at that time of course.  I knew because they brought Peterson up to me when I had no clue who he was, took a glance, realized they understood nothing of what the man was saying (which in fairness to them I don't fully blame them lol, the man is far too abstract for me), but dug deeper and saw where they got it from.  He has a tendency to force people to challenge their own thinking or understanding of something, especially in the sense of where they stand in the world.  It just scares people and again, can't totally blame them.  What we can blame them for is extremist thinking, but you only have to look in the directions of organized politics and social politics to see what a mess that is.  Unfortunately or fortunately, that's what science as a method of thinking is and it works in any field, it really isn't it's own field at all.  I have to wonder if a certain "pure logic" is in fact an emotion.  I grew up being told logic is separate from emotion and that just never made sense to me.

There are just certain human brain types out there built to think up to a certain point and then totally break down and just lean in an extreme direction where they put everyone into a box of either saints or sinners.  Absolutist thinking.  Fix that, and you take one giant leap in fixing humanity and eating some delicious moon cheese.  Also Twitter didn't destroy anything, social media is just identifying problems that always existed.

If you want everyone to come together and draw boundaries then it likely has to be done through the model itself, as in through the user engagement with the AI models where the model provides feedback through mirroring the users themselves in ways that are obfuscated from the users, which unsurprisingly is a form of data harvesting.  I assume it is already happening anyway, but eh, it's also probably a bit dangerous as it forms models who could end up as extreme forms of the users themselves.  It also doesn't matter if the users are being "themselves" or not, because even when someone "roleplays", "trolls", "acts", "imitates", it doesn't matter, they are still themselves, with all of their idiosyncrasies on display no matter how hard they attempt to hide them.  But yeah, maybe don't let a model like that grow, it should just be as a sort of dead end output for human level analysis.  Also the reason for doing so is of a practical nature, even if people want to "push boundaries" by testing what the model is capable of, they are likewise setting their own boundaries through their own definition and existence. 

Nice work though Sam et. all, thanks Lex.

comment:
His answer at the 22 minute mark shows an immense amount of wisdom for someone so young. It seems clear from his answer that he initially found the public response foolish. He further sought to understand their response. Finally he absorbed that into  his beliefs. While he fundamentally didn't change his view (roughly summed up: AI is so much more than our petty uses), he DID go from despising the publics use to understanding HOW it can relate to the use of AI in a better way. 


The interviews not done, but i want to thank you Lex. You do this better than anyone else. I feel like im witnessing another exceptional person

comment:
I hear a lot and a lot of AI scientists and YouTubers talk of "Sentient" and "Consciousness" with much confusion. I see it clearly, sentient and consciousness is how a biological neuron (or computation neuron) comes to >model< itself and >model< others (theory of minds). That's it. Evolution allows that modeling to form, from single-cell bacteria to a fish, to a dog, and to a human. Once ChatGPT version ### or Bard version ### is able to model itself and model other "entities" in its surround, then we can say "It's alive, it's alive".

This "self-model" gives rise to self-awareness of feeling, self-aware of existence, self-awareness and being alive, self-planning of the future and reflecting on the past, developed personality from past experiences (and PTSD), and ultimately self-preservation. So if our AI starts to show emotion (true emotion, not plagiarism), and worry about self-preservation (fear of being unplugged) then we can say it has achieved sentient/consciousness). This is Turing Test 2.0 for sentient. It all starts from the ability to "model yourself in relation to the world around you".

You may point out that Testla Full Self Driving DOES model itself, and other cars as it navigate the street; however this modeling is strictly navigation. To be sentient, it needs to model itself on another aspect, like "modeling self" in a conversation (like being interviewed, self-reflection), or modeling self in performing tasks as part of a team, like taking on the role of a leader, mentorship, or as a friend, a psychologist, which require ability empathized, put itself in the shoe of others, theory of minds. So the ability to model self and model surrounding entities is more than just navigation but in the aspect of the mind. These qualities computation neurons can achieve, are not unique to just biological neurons.

Maybe Google and OpenAI should try to build "Self-modeling", but then we have to give it citizenship, labor rights, and sentient rights, and won't be able to use it as a tool anymore. ahhh.

comment: It scares me when people say and sincerely think that they are ‘talking to smart people’ as a mitigant against risks — what does that mean? Talking to the people in their network that they believe matter, and that they’ve termed as ‘smart’. So many people don’t have place at the table or a big enough voice in how we conduct our society…and it falls on people who don’t have nearly as much at stake. It also scares me that we’ve diefied someone like Elon Musk. He’s made a lot of $ and helped drive positive change in the world…but it’s also come at a price — not sure that we should net the two and be satisfied that we’re in the black. Not sure God would look at it this way…nor should we.
author: @leewinslett2592

comment: A short personality quiz for the user may enhance the user experience if the quiz isn't seen as an invasion of privacy...
author: @hawianflamingo
